Hi,
I have never used surt scope although it looks very interesting.

What if I have a list of 10000 seeds with all sorts of addresses
having domains, subdomains and strange paths.
I'd give the list to Heritrix which generates the initial scope surt
list from seeds. Maybe it could end up with 100 surts? or 1000

How can I verify before crawling that this group of surts
presents exactly the scope I want? At least it takes a lot of time :)

It would be nice if there still was the old domain/host scope 
available. Using it would be like saying 'don't do any calculations
of your own, just simply crawl these'



--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Mohr (Internet
Archive)" <gojomo@a...> wrote:
> The SurtPrefixScope in Heritrix is more efficient and flexible than
the
> DomainScope, HostScope, or PathScope options, but not as easy to
use or
> understand.
> 
> We've made some improvements to the documentation, specifically at:
> 
> SurtPrefixScope
>   http://crawler.archive.org/articles/user_manua
l.html#surtprefixscope
> 
> SURT glossary entry
>   http://crawler.archive.org/articles/user_manual.html#surt
> 
> SURT prefix glossary entry
>   http://crawler.archive.org/articles/user_manual.html#surtprefix
> 
> If we could make this SURT prefix-based scopes better understood, we
> would phase out the other more basic legacy scopes, or reimplement
them
> in terms of SurtPrefixScope. (Everything they do can also be
achieved
> more through SURT prefixes.)
> 
> SurtPrefixScope could become the default scope, instead of
DomainScope,
> as soon as the upcoming 1.4 release.
> 
> We'd like feedback...
> 
>   - Are SURT options understandable?
> 
>   - How could they be made easier to use/understand/configure?
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
